page.title: 06Crawshaw's Hill
page.content: Crawshaw's Hill is a well-known feature of the landscape in this area. It is a steep hill which rises some 60 metres in a distance of 200 metres. For most of the year it is used by a number of horse owners to graze their ponies and horses.In the middle ages the butts were located here for this was where the young men of the village came to practise their archery.In the early years of the Civil War there was a Royalist artillery emplacement here until it was overrun by a Parliamentarian force in 1643.A fall of snow really brings the hill alive for then it is invaded by young people eager to use their toboggans,sledges and even polythene bags to propel themselves whooping and shrieking on their way to the bottom.
